titlestmt.titleproper: Guide to the Nelson Hayes Papers
titlestmt.author: by Michael L. Forstrom

publicationstmt.publisher: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

profiledesc.creation: This finding aid was produced using ArchivesSpace on Sunday December 9, 2018 at 05:33

repository.corpname: Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library

did.abstract: The Nelson Hayes papers contain correspondence, writings, journals, and other materials documenting the personal and professional life of author Nelson Hayes.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: The materials are open for research.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: The Nelson Hayes Papers is the physical property of the Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library, Yale University. Literary rights, including copyright, belong to the authors or their legal heirs and assigns. For further information, consult the appropriate curator.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: Nelson Hayes Papers. Yale Collection of American Literature, Beinecke Rare Book and Manuscript Library.

processinfo.head: Processing Information
processinfo.p: Preliminary processing was done to the Nelson Hayes papers at an unknown date. During reprocessing of the collection in 2010, the arrangement of correspondence and writings was largely preserved in Series I and II respectively; journals were moved from the writings into a separate series (Series III); unsorted writings were added at the end of the alphabetical sequence in the Writings series (Series II); and subject files were moved into a new Personal Papers series (Series IV).

bioghist.head: Nelson Hayes (1903-)
bioghist.p: Nelson Hayes was born October 9, 1903, in Tr√©pied, Pas de Calais, France, son of Chester Coleman and Henrietta (Andrews) Hayes. He attended the Hotchkiss School and Yale (class of 1925) before marrying Emmy Katherine Clason on December 28, 1925. Hayes's professional employment included work as a secretary and assistant teasurer at Lockwood Manufacturing Co. in South Norwalk, CT (1925-1930), a real estate broker in South Norwalk, CT (1934-1955), and an investment executive in Roxbury, VT (1955-).

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The Nelson Hayes papers contain correspondence, writings, journals, and other materials documenting the personal and professional life of author Nelson Hayes. Materials throughout the collection also document Hayes's special interest in the Caribbean. For example, subject files located in the Correspondence and Personal Papers series, writings, and journals contain clippings, personal observations and commentary, and photographs relating to the Caribbean. Specific writings set in the Caribbean include "Caribbean Junket", Dildo Cay , and "Spanceled". Otherwise, the bulk of the general correspondence in the collection is with Hayes's wife, mother, and two daughters. Correspondence relating to writings consists chiefly of letters from editors about novels, short stories, articles, and other writings. The Writings series contains research files and drafts for various forms of work, such as articles, poems, short stories, and published and unpublished novels. There are typescript copies of Hayes's journals, including research for writings, lists of illustrations, and indices, dating from 1950 to 1970; journals are bound with original correspondence, photographs, and clippings dating from 1922 to 1973. Personal Papers contain a calendar, clippings, and notebooks.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into four series: I. Correspondence, 1915-1973. II. Writings, 1920-1973. III. Journals, undated. IV. Personal Papers, 1971.

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Organized into two subseries: General Correspondence and Correspondence Relating to Writings.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: General correspondence includes family, personal, and professional correspondence. The bulk of the correspondence is with Hayes's wife ("Emmy"), mother, and two daughters ("Ilse" and "Larrier"). There are also subject files on "Public Issues" and the "Virgin Islands" containing correspondence and clippings.

Correspondence Relating to Writings, arranged alphabetically, consists chiefly of letters from editors about novels, short stories, articles, and other writings. There is also correspondence with literary agents and fan mail. The largest group of letters relates to Hayes's best-known novel Dildo Cay .
The correspondence contains some newspaper clippings, notes, and writings.
Additional correspondence can be found among the journals in Series III.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series II, Writings, contains research files and drafts for various forms of work, such as articles, poems, short stories, and published and unpublished novels. Aside from early notes and poems dating from Hayes's time as a student at Yale, most writings date from the early 1930s to early 1970s.

did.unittitle: "Rhythmic Variation and the Natural Manner in Prose"
"The Surest Way to Get Your Buck"

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series III, Journals, contains typescript copies of Hayes's journals covering the period from 1950 to 1970. Journals include research for writings, lists of illustrations, and indices, and are bound with original correspondence, photographs, and clippings dating from 1922 to 1973. Volumes are numbered in chronological order, with individual titles listed in folder headings below. The dates of the period covered are given in brackets, though inscriptions suggest that copies may have been made at a later date.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Series IV, Personal Papers, contains a calendar, clippings or subject files on the Bahamas and the West, and notebooks. Additional clippings on "Public Issues" and the "Virgin Islands" can be found with general correspondence in Series I.
